adjectives.description: abeam (comparative more abeam, superlative most abeam)

entries.meaning: (nautical, aircraft) Alongside or abreast; opposite the center of the side of the ship or aircraft. [Mid 19th century.]
examples: The sound shifted its place markedly, but without coming nearer. It even grew a little more distant right abeam of the lighter, and then ceased again.

adverbs.description: abeam (comparative more abeam, superlative most abeam)

entries.meaning: (nautical, aircraft) On the beam; at a right angle to the centerline or keel of a vessel  or aircraft; being at a bearing approximately 090 Degrees or 270 Degrees relative. [Mid 19th century.]
examples: […]  waves striking the ship abeam pushed her always south of their new course, and rolled her, and filled her with water so that bailing must be ceaseless  […]

entries.meaning: (nautical, aircraft) Alongside or abreast; opposite the center of the side of the ship or aircraft. [Mid 19th century.]

examples: She came abeam the crippled ship.

description: a- +‎ beam (“to emit beams of light”)

entries.meaning: Beaming, shining (especially with reference to a person's face or eyes).
examples: […]  the hearts of the saints [will] be all attention and their faces all abeam for the consolation;
